Description: Warning: May not contain topaz. Or egg.
A map possibly revealing the possible location of possible treasure. Possibly. ※Level 70 full party (8 players) recommended.

A faded map possibly revealing the possible location of a teleportation portal possibly leading to a hidden location possibly filled with untold riches. Possibly. ※Level 70 full party (8 players) recommended.
A ring of vibrant daisies fit for a princess.
A ring of vibrant daisies fit for a princess, seneschal, sultan, or any combination thereof.
This poorly penned and illustrated parchment invites one and all to participate in the Valentione's Ceremony.
Taken from a cache stored in the Orbonne Monastery and discovered by the Dalmascan resistance group Lente's Tears.
The root of an ancient treant, so named for its potent healing properties.
A vial of all-purpose antivenom common among the Night's Blessed.
A seemingly ordinary strip of bark taken from Fruit of the Protector.
A fragrant liquid that, when applied to mushrooms, prevents the premature discharge of spores.
A wild mushroom used to brew tea by the Night's Blessed.
A vibrant gem that almost seems alive in your hands.
A few drops of this fragrant nectar are all it requires to lure out beasts with a sweet tooth.
A rather large leaf of snapmint.
A candle lovingly crafted by the Night's Blessed whose flame is a curious shade of blue.
An account of how the Exarch summoned the Crystal Tower, and the city built by the refugees who sheltered there.
An account of how the Warriors of Light caused the Flood, which later led to the appearance of the sin eaters.
An account of how the races of the Source are known by different names in the First.
Intended for younger readers, this tome featuring winsome illustrations tells the beloved tale of the Oracle of Light.
This foul-tasting serum grants resistance to the effects of dream powder.
Amaro fodder dosed with the serum prince's kiss.
Possessed of a furled tip, this peculiar plant can apparently be used to see hidden pixies.
These seeds will grow into an enchanted grass that, true to its name, produces everblooming flowers.
The sweet and succulent fruit of the belltree, favored by pixies.
Pristine water drawn from Longmirror Lake.
The ghastly leg of a moss fungus.
Words and patterns inscribed using this magical ink cannot be seen by the naked eye.
A longsword showing early signs of rust. Its hilt is stained with what you presume to be the blood of sin eaters.
A chunk of spoiled meat, boiled in a poisonous stew originally invented by Master Matoya.
Found among the windswept crags of Ohl Tahn, these fragrant blooms are prized by dragons and moogles alike.
A wax-sealed envelope addressed to Cassard.
A gold coin in common circulation when the Kingdom of Voeburt was at its peak.
A keepsake once belonging to Toddia of the Night's Blessed.
A handmade candle of the Night's Blessed. It burns an eerie blue when lit.
A handmade device crafted by the Night's Blessed to produce copious amounts of smoke.
A burlap sack large enough to fit a dwarf.
For gods' sake, don't let them out.
A small medallion bearing the image of an owl, the insignia of Ronka.
An account of sightings of a particular sin eater some would claim to be a Lightwarden.
A simple tablet made of clay used to preserve the inscriptions of ancient relics.
A special restorative uniquely crafted to cure poisons concocted by the Children of the Everlasting Dark.
A curious lamp fashioned by Emet-Selch. It seems to resonate with the Lifestream.
A potent medicinal herb that very much smells the part, so named for its pointed leaves.
A bit of paper with “Gondola from cliffs─potential death trap” scrawled upon it.
A bit of paper with “Hills of Amber Trolley─behind gate?” scrawled upon it.
A bit of paper with “Airships─Eulmoran presence confirmed” scrawled upon it.
No one could ever possibly need this many tools, let alone to carry them all on their person at one time.
A chunk of rock taken from a debitage.
Currency minted by the Kingdom of Voeburt.
The acrid smoke from bombs such as this is said to drive knockers into a frenzy.
A chunk of rock taken from the hide of a knocker.
A rare mineral used to power the Talos in the Hills of Amber.
As its name suggests, this alchemical concoction can be used to dispel the effects of a glamour.
A large, jagged tusk plucked from the mouth of a feral swine.
A delicate azure flower commonly found in the woods of Yx'Maja.

A small satchel containing a fine powder comprised mainly of ground mushroom and enchanted with Nu Mou magicks. Useful for dispelling all manner of illusions, save the ones under which we choose to labor.
The tender meat of a blue deer doe.
The lifeblood of a caracal.
An enchanted box designed in the traditional Sharlayan style.
Even without the box's enchantment to hold it in place, the creature has no more fight left in it.
A fragrant herb commonly found growing along the floodplains of the Source.
This bottle contains scented water, the liberal application of which can conceal undesirable odors.
“Coughing. Hoarse. Hard to swallow (feels like something's there?). Sore throat...”
A portion of meol, intended as payment for an apothecary's medicine.
Despite its age and prolonged submersion, this golden medallion still retains its luster.
Leaving everyone at a loss as to who could have penned it.
A foul-smelling solution the Viis claim will soften the exoskeleton of spiders.
This alcohol is so strong that even catching a whiff of it causes a brief dizzy spell.
A stinking bag that you unfortunately know from experience is filled with some manner of manure.
An exceedingly heavy sack filled with assorted leafy greens and root vegetables suitable for consumption by amaro and chocobos.
Untold years spent buried beneath sand and rubble have done little to tarnish this exquisitely crafted piece of jewelry.
Although the location in which it was buried indicates that it is of Nabaath origin, it will need to be thoroughly cleaned before it can be properly inspected.
While you suspect this may simply be a ball of clay with rudimentary eye holes poked into it, an assessment of its true worth is best left to a historian.
A rolled bit of parchment containing a plea for volunteers to assist in menial tasks at Spagyrics.
Gently glowing nectar that has a sweet, alluring aroma, but is far too rare and difficult to harvest to ever consider drinking. Seriously, don't even think about it.
A small portion of the faetail, a plant rendered medicinal through the miracle of science.

This paper contains a list of four Crystarium facilities─Ballistics, the Amaro Launch, Temenos Rookery, and the Cabinet of Curiosity─and points of contact at each. Someone with poor design sense has clearly tried very hard to make it look official.
A variety of sweet that Urianger supposedly loathes.
Portraying a location in Il Mheg, this picture shows leafmen who appear to be gathered for some unknown event.
Portraying a location in Il Mheg, this picture shows leafmen who appear to be bathing at the lake.
Perhaps the amphisbaena from which you took this backbone will be comforted to know that it is being put to good use.
A thick and juicy cut of one of the Ondo's staple foodstuffs.
Fresh from the cookfire, piping hot and ready for a taste test.
It may surprise you to learn that this skin, taken from a hardskin stingray, is indeed quite tough and resilient.
The product of an Ondo craftsman's distinct aesthetic sensibilities, this accessory may well fetch a high price in the right market.
Though you cannot actually see the letter, it seems safe enough to assume based on the envelope, which has clearly been cried upon rather a lot, that it will have been marred by falling tears.
A hastily scribbled memo reading “Voeburt muffins─like mother used to make.”
A hastily scribbled memo reading “novelty dishes─non-Voeburtite cuisine.”
A hastily scribbled memo reading “Kholusian stew─pre-Flood tradition.”
A sturdy plank of wood that once formed part of a sunken ship.
The insignia engraved upon this ring is difficult to make out.
A gaudy circlet on which is displayed what appears to be the crest and motto of a noble house.
An elegant necklace engraved with what appears to be the motto of a noble house.
A needlessly large, expensive-looking ring.
A mysterious fluid that smells suspiciously like cured meats.
Developed at the Crystalline Mean, this alchemical powder swiftly induces slumber.
Developed at the Crystalline Mean, this alchemical powder swiftly induces slumber.
Durable pickaxes crafted by the Tholls, adapted for use by bigger folk.
A curious orb that will allow you to harness the power of creation and give form to the concept within.
Curious construction notwithstanding, it is still fundamentally a rope, and there are only so many ways one can use a rope.
As one might expect, the creature is rather less than pleased to have been bound and shoved in your pack.
Fresh and creamy sheep's milk. Freshest and creamiest, if you ask the pixies.
Comprised of tightly woven seaweed, this rope should serve well in satisfying your myriad rope needs.
The creature unceremoniously stuffed into this crate struggles in vain for freedom, as if they know what terrible designs Saushs Koal has for their teeth.
A collection of goods Cassard ordered from the merchants of Mord Souq.
Perfect for small-scale conflagrations and children's parties.
Once upon a time, this blind, tunneling creature had a much more respectable name.
Whether this foodstuff is suitable for vegetarians is the subject of much debate.
This mixture containing the finely ground remains of sand wrigglers stimulates the olfactory senses of the Mord, resulting in an effect similar to gaelicatnip on cats.
Crumpled and covered in smudges, you can only pray that the recipient is able to decipher the contents.
The beautiful penmanship is a stark contrast to that of the intended recipient, and the flowing cursive script may even be too elegant for him to read.
This compact parcel would make a half-decent murder weapon if the lethal blow were not cushioned by the countless layers of cloth wrapping.
Crafted for a very specific purpose and entirely useless for absolutely everything else.
As in “the secretions of a succulent” rather than “secretions that are succulent.”
Several parchment bills notarized by Clan Nutsy stating the reward for the slaying of certain wanted monsters.
Several parchment bills notarized by Clan Nutsy stating the reward for the slaying of certain wanted monsters.
Several parchment bills notarized by Clan Nutsy stating the reward for the slaying of certain wanted monsters.
A parchment bill notarized by Clan Nutsy stating the reward for the slaying of a certain notorious and deadly monster.
Some moss is not meant to be gathered through gentle scraping, but with a disproportionate display of force.
Scrawled in your own hand, the note says “11 in stack near Irvithe.”
Scrawled in your own hand, the note says “24 in stack by entrance.”
Scrawled in your own hand, the note says “68 in storehouse, 9 discarded. 13 delivered, 1 damaged.”
A species of vine that boasts beautiful spirals, curls, and, of course, whirls.
This pink flower sequestered within this small pouch exudes a mysterious sense of snugness.
A spyglass on loan from the chipper pixie for use in their game.
An ancient-looking handscroll with a cover of the darkest black.
The spores of a variety of mushroom grown by the Nu Mou.
This bag is stuffed full of flower seeds cultivated by the pixies.
Native to the waters of Il Mheg, this beautiful lily is at the peak of its bloom.
An envelope containing a scrap of parchment bearing fae runes, fashioned in the likeness of an ancient text.
This old sword has been polished to a mirrorlike sheen.
It is said that the meat from around the creature's independently moving eyes is particularly delicious. This chunk, however, is from its rump.
Not only will this pungent substance keep Amber iguanas at bay, it has a similar effect on almost everything with a nose.
The number of teeth marks around the spout suggests that this bottle has been taken on many arduous desert treks over the years.
Although this sorry excuse for a digging implement is more rust than metal, the fact that it is marginally more resilient than the ground means it should still be up to the task. Barely.
Judging by the obvious cheapness of this old, wooden chest, it is unlikely to contain anything of value.
This glittering rock led a quiet, peaceful existence before becoming the plaything of a slightly deranged child.

Although oils such as this are used to soften lizard hide, this is normally performed after its owner is killed and skinned. What effect, if any, this will have on a living creature remains to be seen.
Rendered pliant by the succulent smell of sausages.
Is it a sauté or is it a soup? Whichever it is, this traditional Nu Mou dish is positively delectable.
The lusty blood of a phooka, to be used in the cultivation of mushrooms.
The crystalline heart of an undine, to be used in the cultivation of mushrooms.
The sturdy silk of a psammead, to be used in the cultivation of mushrooms.
A moss fungus leg so fresh, it's still kicking.
A cruel-looking thorn taken from a witchweed.
Simple but sturdy, this sack can be used to capture an echevore.
The echevore held inside is submissive...for the time being.

A timeworn skin map revealing the location of an unknown treasure.

※Level 80 recommended.

A timeworn skin map revealing the location of an unknown treasure.

※Level 80 full party (8 players) recommended.

A faded map revealing the location of a teleportation portal leading to a hidden dungeon filled with untold riches.

※Level 80 full party (8 players) recommended.
※Average item level 505 recommended.
×未使用
This viscous liquid retrieved from a triffid gives off an acrid aroma.
The sinewy, stretchy tendon of a sandskin sibilus.
This simple fishing rod has seen better days.
The colors of this necklace have become faint and clouded with moisture.
The metal of this ring has succumbed to large patches of rust.
A bivalve mollusk known for hiding succulent flesh within a steel-hard exterior. This one is a particularly large specimen.
A short, sturdy blade made of hammered mythril.
This picture is a faithful recreation of the mural found at the Qitana Ravel.
This profusion of brightly glowing coral-like branches is most definitely not a kettle.
Application documents requesting permission to enter the Capitol as a sanctioned visitor.
An official writ of permission granting you entry to the Capitol as a sanctioned visitor.
A sturdy length of rope useful for binding subdued game birds.
This sack is big enough to hold a trussed-up tragopan.
This sack jerks violently with the thrashing of its angry feathered occupant.
A fragrant herb native to the island of Kholusia.
This tiny pouch exudes the powerfully pleasant aroma of Kholusian sage.
A harvesting knife borrowed from a potion-maker. He wants it back.
A piece of papery bark which serves as an ingredient for various herbal concoctions.
A pouch full of brown-colored pellets. Take three a day to settle upset stomachs.
A long stalk of barley, colored a rather striking shade of gold.
Ale so smooth, it's said to slide down one's throat like honeyed sunshine.
This jar holds the red-tinted dust of a ground-up fire crystal.
A vibrantly colored flower picked from the Split Hull.
This blue-streaked coal serves as fuel for various dwarven contraptions.
A worn sack on loan from the amaro Sandman.
A yellow-hued mineral that can be crushed and spread on a field as an effective fertilizer.
The enticing smell of cured meat rises from this hefty burlap sack.
The contents of this dripping burlap sack have been thoroughly chilled by the rushing waters of Watts River.
This roughly sawn wood appears to have been left to weather the elements for long years.
A penitent note from a Eulmoran noblewoman.
A crystal spike-laden wing, sheared from a cliffkite.
A chunk of stone taken from a pulverized huldu.
A letter of introduction addressed to Szem Djenmai, and signed by the Crystal Exarch.
A set of documents required to register as a bonded citizen of Eulmore.
Although technically “Ronitt's hammer,” this priceless family heirloom first belonged to Watts, the legendary dwarven blacksmith.
A container sealed shut with blood-smeared talismans.
The text on this page outlines a plan to irreparably upset the balance of the Rak'tika Greatwood.
A plump and squirming grub, irresistible to cliffmoles.
This sturdy burlap sack could comfortably accommodate a juvenile cliffmole.
The juvenile cliffmole inside this sack appears to have drifted off to sleep.
The lustrous black color of this coal denotes its superior quality as a fuel.
A core retrieved from the wreckage of the ironbeard killer.
Dwarven explosives, custom-made for the dual purpose of mining and general amusement.
Held at the right angle, this heavy chunk of ore appears to sparkle with tiny points of light.
A small stone, worn smooth by the waters of Watts River.
A length of wire thick enough to restrain a wriggling Gulg knocker.
A subdued Gulg knocker, enmeshed in loops of thick wire.
Having spent most of its life fending for itself on the plains, the meat of this particular lizard is much tougher than that of its domesticated brethren.
A list of merchandise purchased by Cassard and awaiting collection.
Why go to the hassle of procuring your own bait when you can hire someone to do it for you?
A viscous sap that the pixies use to make their paint.
Coming in a variety of colors, this flower grows wild and abundant in the fields of Il Mheg.
The crumpled paper and shoddy manner in which the missive has been sealed indicate that it was prepared in a hurry.
Fortunately, the soulstone remained unscathed despite its owner being smashed to smithereens.

This expertly brewed Crystarium ale continues a long tradition of bearing a seemingly unfathomable name. It is said that the first person to take a swig was so impressed by its robust, earthy notes that she was left quite speechless, with only her raised eyebrow any indication of the impression it had made on her.
Specially designed to prevent the naked flame within from coming into contact with dangerous gases present in the mines.
Even in the dim glow of a safety lamp, this many-faceted gem emits a dazzling sparkle. It beggars belief that the miner who lost it was unable to find it by himself.
It is hard to imagine that coins could have become this rusty in the years since the Ronso left Kelk, so it seems that they were kept as historic artifacts rather than as valid currency.
Why the Ronso, like so many other races, choose to depict their people's history on pieces of tableware is anyone's guess.

The numerous scratches and gouge marks indicate that someone went to great lengths to prise this chest open, while the fact they then discarded it implies they were displeased with the bizarre assortment of knickknacks inside.
Years of being used to hook tasty morsels from between crags have worn away at this knife's once sharp edge, though a careless slip could still lead to a nasty gash.
This repulsive invertebrate's highly viscous blood renders it entirely inedible to all but the most desperate of desert dwellers.

It is commonly believed that striped stones are formed inside the bodies of gnomes, with the age of the creature indicated by the number of stripes. Whether a single band indicates a period equal to a year, a decade, or a century is the cause of much debate among geologists.
Its compact size means that it could be buried in a relatively shallow hole in the ground, while its weight suggests that there is something other than stale air inside.
Made from the precious stone known as “cat's-eye” rather than an actual feline eyeball, which would be a poor choice for a variety of reasons.
While it is unclear what causes this oil to emit such a distinctive and unpleasant smell, it is perhaps best not to ask.
Not only is it exquisitely decorated, it also appears to be far too large and cumbersome to be carried by a miner at work.
Although the Talos from which these parts were requisitioned has lain dormant for many years, the inner workings have been shielded from the elements and are in remarkable condition.
The dints and scratches that cover the metallic surface may have been incurred during the extraction process.
The durable outer casing of a Talos is almost impossible to open without one of these purpose-built tools.
The brutal manner in which phorusrhacidae slay and devour their prey means that only the feathers that grow from the tail escape being covered in copious amounts of blood.
Harlolth must be a trusting soul indeed to hand such a heavy coinpurse to a complete stranger.
Store in a cool, dry place. Keep out of reach of children.
It is said that thistle moles rely on their fat reserves for survival when food is scarce. Extracting the substance from their carcasses is not a job for the faint of heart.
Heating and stirring thistle mole fat to produce oil is a simple but malodorous affair.
The tender meat of a blue deer stag.
A succulent-looking mushroom found in the forest of Yx'Maja.
Chock-full of nutrients, this liver is ideal for young Ondo clutchmothers.
Though not particularly uncommon, it takes a discerning eye to pick out shells of the highest quality that are fit for use in artistic endeavors. Fortunately, you possess such an eye.
There are plenty of anemones in the sea─less the ones you slew to procure rope-making materials.
Some items warrant no description.
A worn sack bearing a bottle of pristine water.
A lamp that glows with the magic of the pixies.
Looking at this necklace's well-worn cord, it is easy to see how it would have snapped readily as its wearer fled Holminster Switch.
An accessory selected after long deliberation by the Crystarium's merchants.
Food prepared with care by the Crystarium's vegetable growers.
Juice squeezed with great effort by Crystarium children and their botany instructor.
An alarmingly inky-looking concoction that smells strongly of vinegar and medicinal herbs.
A tiny pouch packed with an assortment of foul-smelling herbs.
This hearty sandwich is sure to provide comfort to the stomach, if nothing else.
This ground spice made from peppercorns native to Kholusia is often used by the residents of Gatetown to disguise the flavor of rotting meat.
Hand-selected peppercorns of the highest quality, finely ground into a spice suitable for use by the gourmet chefs of Eulmore.
Although the aroma is pleasing at first, the novelty soon wears off when it persists on clinging to the fingertips even after extended bouts of scrubbing.
While not all of the flotsam that washes onto the shores of Kholusia is suitable for being used as building material, many local beggars find they are in no position to be choosers.

Any beachcomber worth their salt would be a fool to pass up such a fine piece of wreckage. Strong enough to hold up even the most rickety of shacks, it also doubles as a handy cudgel in times of emergency.
Used by the pixies of Il Mheg to make a mildly intoxicating punch. Strangely enough, the word “punch” often comes to the minds of those who encounter the fae folk when they are in their cups.

A punch made from this particularly potent strain of sap can keep a pixie in a drunken stupor for days on end. Thankfully, the catastrophic hangover that ensues is normally ample punishment for any mischief they may have caused.
If you think carrying a bunch of logs around is backbreaking work, try doing it after they have been left to soak in water for goodness knows how long.
A whole bag of these should be worth at least a cow.

From these distinctive shrubs grow the tears of Yx'Lokwa, used as offerings in various ceremonies. The plants themselves are said to repel pests, although the stench is powerful enough to scare off just about anyone.
The oily coating on this rare shrub emits an odor so overwhelming that nearby plants are often seen growing away from it.
Known for growing extraordinarily slowly, the keepers of the Greatwood must ensure that botanists refrain from harvesting too much lest supplies dwindle.
Since even a small nibble can send one into a deep slumber, the trees on which this algae grows are often surrounded by inquisitive deer snoring contentedly.
It is said that even touching this potent variety of dream algae with bare skin can result in one instantly losing consciousness. Gloves are a must when handling this rare crop.
Despite being dried in the arid desert plains of Amh Araeng, this discarded wood is an excellent building material, provided it is kept well away from open flames.
Some botanists claim that the oil within nourishes the plant in its first days after sprouting. When used to make cooking oil, the distinctive fragrance enhances even the most basic of meals.
The patients who drink the medicine made from this hardy plant are usually not told its name for fear they might gag on the mixture.
The finer examples of this robust shrub are said to even more closely resemble the fine fuzz that covers the posteriors of its namesakes.
Its reputation for being resistant to water and other liquids makes it an ideal choice for casks.
Being almost entirely impervious to woodworm makes this oak ideal for items built to last.
When the plants are allowed to grow large enough, the leaves resemble elves's ears, though the owners of said ears vehemently deny this for some reason.
This algae-like plant lines the lakebed of the Source, and when viewed from above the water's surface, appears akin to a grassy meadow.
Little is known about this strange aquatic plant, and whether these protrusions are indeed sprouts is a matter of much debate among botanists.
Though few would argue that this distinctive stone deserves a place amongst fine gemstones and the like, it nonetheless possesses a unique appeal for the discerning collector.
Even in its uncut state, it makes for an attractive paperweight.
It is best to avoid saying the name of this substance near the coastal region's female residents.
Quite how this differs from iron ore found anywhere else would require a lengthy explanation that no one with sense could possibly be interested in.
For most metalworkers dealing with such materials, “exceptional” is another word for “big.”
Many claim it to possess arcane properties, and is a popular choice for charms and such.
The lost Kingdom of Voeburt once used rocks such as these to line the walls of their defensive structures due to its unique magical properties.
Although many people would assume that all sapphires are blue, they in fact come in a variety of colors. Like pink, for example.
Supposedly, this crystal will protect the bearer from all manner of evils and misfortunes. Whether this includes the mischievous residents of Il Mheg remains to be seen.
Worryingly, this peculiar substance is not as rare as one might expect. Proof─if any were needed─that Rak'tika has more than its fair share of suspicious characters.

For gravel to become coated in poison to this extent would require multiple applications, meaning that the substance in question was spilled at the same location more than once. Given the Children of the Everlasting Dark's proclivity for mixing poison, this is not as unlikely as it sounds.
The green coloration makes this valuable gem surprisingly hard to find among the lush vegetation of Rak'tika.
Said to have splintered off from Fruit of the Protector, an enormous crystal that predates the Ronkan Empire.
Fragments of Fruit of the Protector come in various shapes and sizes, but only a few are considered to be perfect.
When ground into a fine powder, it is capable of negating the effects of most poisons. Much trial and error was required before this remedy was discovered, however.
Once used in ancient Nabaath Areng as a base ingredient in a range of alloys.
Though the passing of time has not been kind to the abandoned Talos, the parts less exposed to the elements may still be used.
The alloy from which such parts were crafted is almost entirely impervious to corrosion.

Those charged with fortifying the defensive walls of the Crystarium will accept just about any materials they can get their hands on. This should help fill in some of the larger cracks that have appeared.
It would be wasteful to leave such fine building materials to gather moss in Lakeland.
While certainly a rare stone, its popularity pales in comparison with better-known gems. It is, however, favored by connoisseurs who have grown tired of the usual emeralds, rubies, and the like.
Though it may appear to many as a fine, uncut jewel, it is in fact nothing more than a lump of hardened salt. Its true value is revealed when it is ground down and used in medicine.

While it may be little more than crystallized salt, it is nonetheless considered to be attractive enough to be used in jewelry. Its scrapings may also be used as seasoning when supplies of regular salt run low.
A flame-colored, tube-like arrangement of petals, heavy with magma grass seeds.
The twitching tail of an upland iguana.
A freshly fermenting barrel of dwarven-style ale.
This sturdy length of wood will help any traveler navigate their way through treacherous mountain passes.
The scribblings on this sheet of parchment ostensibly carry great meaning to the person who penned them.
A small bag containing samples of sand, rocks, saliva, and so forth harvested for research purposes.
A massive, timeworn chain once used in an ancient prison.
A mighty slab of stone with a string of numbers etched into it.
Whatever door this key once opened doubtless no longer stands.
An order from the Crystarium guard to the fishermen of Sullen for a sizable quantity of dried fish.
A Sullen specialty, painstakingly smoked and dried to produce a mouthwatering aroma.
Made from fish pickled in sea brine, this savory snack is a Knot specialty.
Fat and juicy worms ideally suited for fish bait writhe and squirm in this sack.
A simple wooden crate that you unearthed at the spot marked on the map. What treasures could it hold?
Shimmering nectar so sweetly fragrant it may as well have come straight out of a faerie tale.

This fractured piece of earthenware was once part of an urn used to store poison. Although the contents have long since been removed, it would still be advisable to wash your hands after touching such an object.
Even a scholar well versed in the ways of the ancient Ronkans would struggle to identify this bizarre relic.
After the feathers of a tarichuk have been made into arrow flights, the oily sheen reduces wind resistance.
According to local myths, this coral gains its distinctive color by feeding on the blood of those slaughtered by clionids.
This glistening globule of solidified oyster excretions is said to resemble the eyes of an ancient king.
A large box containing building materials and other essential supplies bound for the Ostall Imperative.
Lake anemone seeds are one of Lakeland's lesser-known exports, largely due to the fact that collecting them is such an unpleasant and perilous task.
This popular ale was named after one of the regulars in the establishment where the brew was perfected. Rumors that said patron was also involved in the carbonation process are unfounded.
One piece taken from a stockpile that could have found its way out of the Ostall Imperative in any number of ways.
According to some patrons, it is the only mulled wine available at Clearmelt, thus making it the finest by default.
Partially digested and still dripping with saliva and stomach juice, this sturdy leather sack seems to have miraculously protected its contents from significant damage.
A pail filled to the brim with a sticky substance perfectly suited for patching up castle walls.
A medicinal tincture supplied to the Crystarium guard to ease wounds and soothe aches and pains.
A piece of parchment detailing an extensive array of building materials and other supplies needed at the Ostall Imperative.
The experience of biting into this juicy fruit is best described as hosting a fête inside your mouth to which everyone has been extended an invitation.
Contrary to the spearfisher's dismissive description, this collection of fresh fish is not all that disappointing. Perhaps he simply has exceedingly high standards?
In keeping with the time-honored tradition of using the flesh of a small creature to lure out a larger one.
Entrusted to you by Amshs Aath, this Ondo creation can be employed during your battle with the amphisbaena to befuddle its senses and improve your chances.
Hopefully these scales will serve to shield the Ondo better than they did the amphisbaena before them.
Though a skilled merchant can surely sell anything, they would struggle marginally less to do so were these items their wares. Possibly.
A heavy slab of stone you assume bears writings on Ronkan mythology.
The bloated carcass of an anemone.
A nondescript scrap of paper unceremoniously dumped on the beach by a long-since-departed faire-goer.
A now-useless fishing rod unceremoniously dumped on the beach by a long-since-departed faire-goer.
A bottle deprived of its contents and unceremoniously dumped on the beach by a long-since-departed faire-goer.
This modestly sized bottle appears to house a missive of sorts.
A clay tablet with impressions of ancient scripture.
Removing this letter from its glass house has sadly done little to enlighten you as to the import of the words writ upon it.
A brown paper parcel tied up with string, like as not to contain a few of Chathwick's favorite things.
Food lovingly prepared by Heggie.
Produces a high-pitched tone to which Crystarium amaro have been conditioned to respond.
A large chunk of triffid, oozing with sap.
A prime piece of timber harvested from a forest infested with terrible triffids.
A rare ore found on Mt. Gulg. Its refractive properties are essential in creating the precision clockwork components of dwarven automata.
This cane has clearly been worn by exposure to the elements over the course of many years.
A treasure prepared by the pixies for use in the game of treasure hunt.
The bloated carcass of an anemone.
A small, crude harpoon easily wielded even by small children.
A psammead leg so fresh, it's still kicking.
A crate of flawless craftsmanship, but whence it came you cannot say.
This journal's pages are filled with notes about places all across Norvrandt.
A quiver's worth of handcrafted arrows.
A blanket of huggably soft fur, perfect for keeping a newborn babe warm. The now hairless animal whence it came surely misses it dearly...
Crystal-clear water gathered from the trickling dewdrops of the forest's trees.
A pair of simple earrings carved from the bark of a tree.
A lilybell plucked from the woods of Yx'Maja.
A ring expertly carved from the bark of a tree.
True to its name, this nectar has a rich golden hue, and gives off a seductively sweet scent.
These enchanted scales seem ready to take to the air at any moment.

Haddock so fresh its accusatory stare compels you to toss it back to the sea that it may live a long and fruitful life.

※Not included in the fish guide.
A pack of mushrooms lovingly grown by the Nu Mou.
A curious concoction you received from the still-curiouser tall Fuath in return for a pack of mushrooms.
Boasting medicinal properties, this herb was once the specialty of the kingdom which bears its name.
A nameless flower boasting an elegant blue hue.
A nameless flower boasting a bright-yellow hue.
A nameless flower boasting a winsome pink hue.
The tail of a green glider, freshly parted from its owner's body and still twitching.
A blanket of traditional Nu Mou weave, providing superior warmth.
The plush fleece of a rabbit's tail.
The velvety feathers of a tot aevis.
The luxurious pelt of a phooka.
An old silver medallion inscribed with the word “Nimbus.”
The thick eggshell of an amaro, weatherworn but presumably fit for Rispa's purposes.
A vial of dried medicinal herbs prepared by the Viis.
A leather sack large enough to fit a dwarf, perhaps, but nothing more.
How a Greatwood rail could fit in this sack is anyone's guess.
A lockbox identifiable as Voeburtite by virtue of its ornamentation.
A set of flowing garments worn by the archers of Fanow.
A flower whose petals bear the insignia of Ronka.
A simple loaf of bread baked with nuts and berries.
A handwritten letter whose contents are not meant for your eyes.
The heart of a djinn, said to be the source of their power over wind.
A delicate azure flower said to be blessed by Yx'Lokwa.
The heart of a Ronkan stone sentinel, brimming with aetheric energy.
The glowing heart of a Scree gnome.
This ale has been fortified with the powdered heart of a Scree gnome.
The riddle of the miner's buried treasure is written in Drery's distinctive hand on paper that is practically made of crumples.
Left behind by Daedalus Stoneworks following its withdrawal from Amh Araeng, this timber is still remarkably sturdy despite having been exposed to the elements for many years.
The numerous scrolls and books stuffed inside do little to drown out the clanking of the metallic measuring instruments and cooking utensils.
Though such blooms are commonplace in more fertile lands, they are rarely seen in the barren plains of Amh Araeng.
For use with any number of mining automata, and to further the grand secret designs of two young dwarves.

Like any other lantern, but for use in mines, hence the distinction─though it invites the question of whether or not any lantern used in a mine would then automatically be designated a “mining lantern” by virtue of its location at said point in time...
This average-sized bottle appears to contain a missive of sorts.
This sizable bottle appears to contain a missive of sorts.
This potent tonic invented by Beq Lugg during the time of Voeburt is said to revitalize the soul both figuratively and literally.
A finely grained soil material found in Amh Araeng.
A polished, gem-encrusted accessory that appears rather valuable.
Is it a part of the enigmatic “key,” or a fashionable accessory? Who knows? Not you!
You haven't the slightest idea what this might be for. Perhaps, in this case, that is a good sign.
The longer you stare at this odd piece of metal, the less you know what it is.
Is it a part of the enigmatic “key,” or a fashionable accessory? Who knows? Not you!
You haven't the slightest idea what this might be for. Perhaps, in this case, that is a good sign.
The longer you stare at this odd piece of metal, the less you know what it is.
A hastily written note which reads “Boutique of Splendors─willing to work with Master Chai to rebuild businesses.”
A hastily written note which reads “Eulmore's army─willing to hire recruits from the Derelicts and Gatetown.”
A hastily written note which reads “Kholusians─seeking work. Chai-Nuzz offering employment?”
A fleecy, fluffy ball of thick, soft sheep's wool.
This flower basket, rendered tiny by fae magicks, is still recovering from battle.
From the leafy to the gossamer, the hairy to the slimy, this collection comprises every manner of insect wing you could imagine.
Blossoms as beautiful as these are only found in the hardest-to-reach heights of Il Mheg.
A collection of smooth and shapely stones collected from the shore of Longmirror Lake.
Branches and leaves pruned from a leafman who is now looking more dapper.
The severed rear appendage of a woodland creature. One can suck on it to drink deep of sweet nectar─not that you would know such things.
Voeburtite treasures dredged up from the House of the First Light, deep beneath the surface of Longmirror Lake.
A handful of petals from the enigmatic plant known as witchweed.
A piece of machina that you recognize from your terrifying flight across chasms. This one, however, seems unresponsive.
A piece of machina that you recognize from your terrifying flight across chasms. This one, however, seems unresponsive.
Tiny and irresistibly fluffy, these plants are ideal for tickling noses and toes.
A thick and fleshy cap that has been separated from a now-bareheaded moss fungus.

If the unfortunate glider that gave its life knew what you intend to do with the beautiful wings ripped from its still-warm corpse, it would surely be turning in its grave. If it had a grave to turn in, that is.
The high altitude at which this grass grows provides it with a form of natural protection from sheep too clumsy to climb steep, rocky precipices. Which is most of them.
Though it stands to reason other fragments of whatever this once was are probably not far away, seeking them all out would be a task more tedious and menial than perhaps any you have ever faced.

If spending an indefinite period of time being eroded by the river's icy cold currents is enough to strip the bark from a piece of driftwood, imagine perhaps the same method could be used to remove stubborn stains from dirty dishes, though the likelihood of retrieving them in one piece would be incredibly slim.

It is a common misconception that “Fruits of the Forest” is a generic name applied to a mixture of berries, apples, and so forth used to fill pies and tarts. It is in fact referring to a single ingredient, namely, this.
While it may not be the prettiest or most valuable of stones, if Uin Nee's magic works as planned, it will soon take pride of place in the fabulously gaudy environs of Lyhe Mheg.
If the fish are foolish enough to swim into the basket but not back out again, they deserve to be eaten, though Uin Nee may have other plans for them...
The crystal core of the mysterious water spirit exudes a palpable chill, and could probably be used to keep a drink cool indefinitely.
One of the many floral followers found blooming near the marchioness.
A still-writhing vine severed from an anemone.
A suspicious-smelling potion brewed to help a maiden of Cyril─wherever that is─in dream-matters of the dream-heart.
Alas, its contents are entirely in fae, and thus illegible to you. But you can guess.
This bag has been magically woven and expanded via pixie magic.
A large bag filled out by the form of an excitable, continually kicking phooka.
An immature version of Pla Enni's massive fungi. Presumably. It's definitely a mushroom, anyway.
Sturdy fiber harvested from an─at that point─aggressive psammead.
Still hot to the touch, this bottle of mulled wine will help to keep Thomelin warm through his shift.

A hefty sack of celebratory cakes, made with pounded rice painstakingly carved from the flesh of a monstrous mochi blob. These traditional sweets are guaranteed fresh and most assuredly safe to eat...probably.
Raw and unrefined, this material must be processed at a work station prior to assembly.
Raw and unrefined, this material must be processed at a work station prior to assembly.
Raw and unrefined, this material must be processed at a work station prior to assembly.
Raw and unrefined, this material must be processed at a work station prior to assembly.
Raw and unrefined, this material must be processed at a work station prior to assembly.
Raw and unrefined, this material must be processed at a work station prior to assembly.
Masterfully processed by your hands, this building material is ready for assembly.
Masterfully processed by your hands, this building material is ready for assembly.
Masterfully processed by your hands, this building material is ready for assembly.
Masterfully processed by your hands, this building material is ready for assembly.
Masterfully processed by your hands, this building material is ready for assembly.
Firewood elevated to art by your hands. Any brazier would be stoked to have this.
The scarcely recognizable remains of an item once treasured by a proud Voeburtite king of old.
The scarcely recognizable remains of an item once treasured by a proud Voeburtite king of old.
This well-worn broom has seen many a spring and summer in Slitherbough, swishing and sweeping, sweeping and swishing.
This bulging sack makes a truly heinous squelching noise as you heft it over your shoulder.
A decent-sized hunk of crystal alight with aetherial energies.
Signed by Gerald and bearing the official seal of the Krakens, this contract officially authorizes trade with House Durendaire of Ishgard.
Bearing the rose of House Haillenarte, this envelope contains an entreaty for cooperation in the restoration effort.
Though these scraps of wood are too small for construction, they can still be used in smaller applications.
Made with a time-honored Qitari recipe, this fertilizer has found favor with the denizens of Slitherbough.
Exquisitely etched with the image of a Viis, this adornment is believed to be a relic of ancient Ronka.
If the value of a coffer's contents could be judged by its weight, you might think this one contained all the wealth of Ronka. Unfortunately, it might just as likely contain all the dirt.
Large enough to comfortably hold a chicken─or a chicken-sized Lalafell, if the task required it.
Judging by the sounds coming from this sack, the chicken inside has become quite comfortable in its new home.
Among the Qitari, chicken eggs hold as much value as even the most precious of gemstones.
Pounded into tiny fragments by your mighty hammer blows, this debris is ready for disposal.
Raw and unrefined, this material must be processed at a work station prior to use.
Masterfully processed by your hands, this repair material is ready for use.
Raw and unrefined, this material must be processed at a work station prior to use.
Masterfully processed by your hands, this building material is ready for use.
A colorful bounty of vegetables freshly harvested from the plots of Slitherbough.
A sachet holding a small amount of a herbal remedy traditionally favored by the Viis.
Decorative eggs blessed by the elementals of the Twelveswood, each housing a lightly sweetened cookie inside.
Decorative eggs slippery to the touch, each housing a golden hairpin with an egg motif inside.
The size of these decorative eggs makes them stand out from the rest.
A fine powder blended in the Near Eastern island nation of Radz-at-Han designed to promote aetherial conductivity.
Documents detailing the Scions' planned operations for the next several weeks.

The legacy of Minfilia's father, who perished in the parade incident of 1562 when a goobbue broke free of its magical fetters and ran amok through the streets of Ul'dah. Contains a wealth of stolen imperial research on the primals, as well as other information which has yet to be deciphered.
A hammer designed to fit in the claws of any enterprising dragon or dragonet wishing to learn the fine art of crafting.
